ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Optical spectroscopy of a-plane-oriented ZnO epilayers grown by plasma-assisted molecular beam epitaxy

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Groupe Physique des Solides et Sciences des Matériaux
Affiliation.OrgName: Faculté des Sciences et Techniques, Université Cheikh Anta Diop de Dakar (UCAD)

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Centre de Recherche sur l’Hétéro-Epitaxie et ses Applications
Affiliation.OrgName: Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CRHEA-CNRS)

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: a-plane ZnO layers were successfully grown, by plasma-assisted molecular beam epitaxy, on r-plane (011–2) sapphire substrates. Several features attributed to the A, B and C free excitonic transitions are identified through temperature-dependent photoluminescence (PL) and reflectivity measurements. The temperature dependence of the peak energy positions of these transitions was studied from 8 K to 300 K. So, the PL peak energy of the A free exciton was plotted and fitted with a Varshni empirical equation. In the σ polarization (E⊥c), for which A and B are allowed, the reflectivity spectrum measured at 8 K was fitted by using a program based on the theory of the spatial resonance dispersion Hopfield model. Our results indicate that the A and B free excitonic features are at a higher energy than those in ZnO on c-oriented sapphire and show a good PL even at 250 K. These results also show that the new and intense emission peak observed in the region of the first phonon replica (3.33–3.28 eV) and identified as a stacking fault in the epilayer disappears at high temperature above 150 K.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: As a wide band gap (E g=3.37 eV) semiconductor, ZnO has attracted considerable attention due to its potential applications, such as ultraviolet light-emitting devices and laser devices [1]. Compared with other wide band gap materials, ZnO has a larger exciton binding energy (60 meV) [2, 3], which paves the way for an intense near band edge excitonic emission at room and even higher temperatures. A notable discovery in ZnO thin film materials is the observation of the ultraviolet (UV)-stimulated emission induced by the exciton–exciton scattering at moderate pumping intensity [4–6]. These results show that ZnO is a suitable candidate for optoelectronic device applications in the ultraviolet region. To obtain an efficient and stable UV exciton emission from ZnO films, it is necessary to know the energy band structure of ZnO. The würtzite ZnO valence band is split into three bands due to the influence of crystal-field and spin–orbit interactions [7, 8].The free exciton transitions from the conduction band to these three valence bands or vice versa are usually denoted by A (also referred to as the heavy hole), B (also referred to as the light hole) and C (also referred to as the crystal-field-split band). The selection rules for optical transitions impose that A and B excitons have large oscillator strength for E⊥c (c represents a crystal axis) and the C exciton for E//c polarization. It is difficult in the photoluminescence spectrum to distinguish these peaks in ZnO films because these excitons have approximate energies and large non-radiative damping constants. For these reasons, it is necessary to study the excitonic emissions of ZnO films in detail by using reflectivity for the determination of the peak position energies. Few studies have been done on a-plane ZnO samples [9, 10].

In this paper, we present a spectroscopic study of a-plane-oriented ZnO grown by molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) on r-plane sapphire substrates. The optical properties of the a-plane ZnO films are studied by the photoluminescence (PL) and reflectivity techniques.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: A 1-μm-thick ZnO film was grown at temperature T g∼500 °C. The growth was performed using solid-source Zn and a RF-activated plasma as the oxygen source. The growth rate was 0.2 μm/h, slightly lower than the optimal growth rate in a c-direction growth. Prior to growth, the r-plane (01–12) sapphire substrates were thermally cleaned and subsequently exposed to oxygen plasma during 5 to 10 min. The growth process was in situ monitored by reflection high energy electron diffraction (RHEED) and a streaky RHEED pattern was maintained throughout the growth, albeit with a slight modulation in the [1–100] azimuth. Ex situ surface morphology was investigated by means of atomic force microscopy (AFM). The structural properties were investigated by high-resolution X-ray diffraction (HRXRD) experiments in high-resolution mode. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) investigations were carried out in a JEOL 2010F field emission gun microscope. The results of these investigations are shown in a previous paper [11]. The optical properties of the structures were studied by using non-resonant photoluminescence excited with the 325 nm line from a He–Cd laser. The emitted light was dispersed using a 0.6 m focal length monochromator equipped with a 1200 lines/mm grating and detected by using a silicon photomultiplier tube (PMT) with conventional lock-in techniques. The chopping frequency was set at 220 Hz. The sample was mounted in an optical cryostat where the temperature could be varied from 8 to 300 K. Reflectivity measurements were obtained by exciting using a standard mercury bulb.

PL and reflectivity studies were performed on the samples in two polarizations σ and π (respectively E⊥c and E//c axes). In such a sample, the c axis of the substrate is in the plane of the ZnO epilayer.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Non-selective PL spectra and reflectivity of the ZnO films are both displayed in Fig. 1a in polarization E⊥c.
Fig. 1
(a) Photoluminescence and reflectivity spectra of a-plane ZnO films in the E⊥c polarization at 10 K. (b) Photoluminescence and reflectivity spectra of a-plane ZnO films in the E//c polarization at 10 K

In this polarization PL emissions are seen in the energy ranges 3.35–3.41 eV, 3.28–3.35 eV and 3.17–3.28 eV. The reflectivity spectrum allows distinguishing the free exciton peak positions. In the E⊥c polarization we found in the reflectivity spectrum two free excitons at energy positions of about 3.398 eV and 3.410 eV. These free excitons are called respectively A and B. The A and B free excitons are not resolved in the PL spectrum measured at 8 K. This is due to the pre-eminence of the bound excitons. In the E//c polarization, only one free exciton is found at 3.438 eV as shown in Fig. 1b. It is called the C free exciton. This behavior of the free excitons as a function of polarization shows that the selection rules for these transitions are respected. Note that these energies were measured at the centers of the reflectivity peaks.

The free excitons were fitted using a program based on the theory of the spatial resonance dispersion Hopfield model [12]. The model relative dielectric constant considered is 1
$$ \varepsilon_{\mathrm{r}} = 1 + \frac{4\pi Ne_{0}^{2}}{m^*} \biggl[ \frac {\omega_{0}^{2} - \omega ^{2}}{(\omega_{0}^{2} - \omega^{2})^{2} + \varGamma^{2}\omega^{2}} \biggr], $$ where the coefficient
$4\pi Ne_{0}^{2}/m^{*}$ is related to the oscillator strength (α), ω 0 is the resonance frequency and e 0=e/4πε 0 with e designated as the elementary charge of the electron.

And, the reflection coefficient R is written as 2
$$ R = \frac{(n - 1)^2 + k_{0}^{2}}{(n + 1)^2 + k_{0}^{2}}, $$ with n the index of the medium and k 0 the extinction coefficient.
The fit parameters are: the energy peak E (eV), the oscillator strength (α), the spectral widening (Γ) and the effective mass (m ∗) of the exciton.

In the E⊥c polarization, the two free excitons A and B were fitted together. A best fit is obtained with the values of parameters presented in Table 1.
Table 1
Values of A and B free exciton energies E (eV), the oscillator strength (α), the spectral widening (Γ) and the effective mass (m ∗) of the exciton obtained by using the Hopfield model

Effective mass (m ∗)

The effective mass remains the same for both excitons and m 0 is the mass of a free electron. These values of the exciton energy, measured at the maxima of the reflectivity peaks, confirm our PL and reflectivity measurements. The value α of higher than 1 for the A free exciton is likely due to the fact that A is fitted together with B as displayed in Fig. 2. These results are in good agreement with the prediction of the selection rules of the optical transitions for the oscillator strength.
Fig. 2
Normalized reflectivity spectrum at 10 K of A–B free excitons. The reflectivity is fitted using a program based on the theory of the spatial resonance dispersion Hopfield model. The parameters used in the fit are the peak energy, the oscillator strength (α), the spectral widening (Γ) and the effective mass (m ∗) of the exciton

In fact, the selection rules for the optical transitions predict a large oscillator strength for the A and B excitons in the E⊥c polarization and a large oscillator strength for the C exciton in the E//c polarization. But, when the sample is c-oriented, the oscillator strength of the C exciton is small and it is difficult to fit the C exciton transitions in such structures. Based on the assignment of the free excitons, the weak peak at 3.360 eV is attributed to the Y line, whereas the I2 bound exciton is the main line on the lower side energy range 3.35–3.41 eV. So, the emissions in the ranges 3.28–3.35 eV and 3.17–3.28 eV are supposed to be the first and the second longitudinal optical phonon replicas, respectively. This assignment is of particular interest, because based on the measured energy separation, the emission at 3.28–3.35 eV is lying in the first longitudinal optical phonon (LO) region. Our first investigation [11] by transmission electronic microscopy (TEM) and selective photoluminescence (SPL) with excitation set lower than the band gap energy (3.33 eV) for two polarizations (E//c axis and E⊥c axis) taken at 8 K indicated that this emission line results from the formation of basal stacking faults as observed in GaN [13] with a 1/6(20–23) displacement vector.

In order to support our peak assignment in the low-temperature PL spectrum, we studied, in σ polarization, the temperature evolution of these peaks. The temperature-dependent PL (8–300 K) was measured and is shown in Fig. 3. It is observed that the intensity of the peak attributed to a bound exciton and the peak associated with free excitons exhibit opposite dependences on temperature. The intensity of the A free exciton increases with temperature up to 95 K and decreases as the temperature is increased further, whereas the intensity of the bound exciton decreases and is not detectable above 110 K. This effect is attributed to the change in thermal occupation of the ground state of free and bound exciton transitions. The reduction in the intensity results from the rapid thermal ionization of the bound excitons with increasing temperature [14]. When the temperature is increasing, the PL intensity of the defect line located at the first longitudinal optical phonon region is decreased. Above 150 K the defect line disappears. We note that above this temperature the spectrum is dominated by the A free exciton and the phonon replicas.
Fig. 3
PL spectra of a-plane ZnO at selected temperatures from 8 to 290 K in the E⊥c polarization. The spectra are displaced vertically

These observations support our assignment and we plot in Fig. 4 the A free exciton PL peak energy exciton and the first and second phonon replicas from 8 K to 300 K. But, because of the broadening of the A and the phonon replica lines, it was difficult to obtain their accurate energy positions above 190 K.
Fig. 4
Temperature-dependent PL of the A free exciton peak energies (▲) measured in the E⊥c polarization and their fit using Varshni’s empirical equation (Eq. (4)) (solid line). The fit matches satisfactorily the peak energy. The first (□) and second (○) phonon replicas and their fits (dashed lines) using Eq. (3) are shown. The value p=0.5 gave the better fit
At low temperature the energy separation of the first phonon replica at the related A excitonic emission is ∼72 meV.

As the temperature is increased, this energy separation becomes decreased and a Maxwell distribution of the carriers [15, 16] can be assumed. The general relation (1) between exciton emission and phonon replicas was used to fit the LO phonon replicas [17]: 3
$$ E_{\mathrm{LO}} = E_{\mathrm{Fx}} - n\hbar\omega+ (p + 0.5kT), $$ where E LO is the energy position of the phonon spectral peaks, E Fx is the exciton energy at k=0, p is an integer equal to 1 or 0, n is the number of phonons involved and ħω is the phonon energy (72 meV). For the first and second phonon replicas, when n is respectively 1 and 2, p takes respectively the values 1 and 0. The fit of 2LO is better than those of 1LO but a slight deviation was observed over 190 K, probably due to the error in determination of the peak position resulting from temperature broadening.

The free exciton A energy positions in PL are fitted as a function of temperature using a Varshni empirical equation [18] 4
$$ E_{\mathrm{FX}}(T) = E(0)_{\mathrm{FX}} - \frac{\delta T^{2}}{\beta+ T}, $$ where E FX(T) is the free exciton energy, δ is a Varshni-constant fitting and β can be related to the Debye temperature. The resulting fit obtained for the A free exciton is presented in Table 2.
Table 2
Values of E(0)Fx, α and β obtained by fitting the A exciton energies by using Varshni’s empirical model
Free exciton
E(0)Fx (eV)
α (meV/K)
β (K)
A
3.399
0.546
500

There is some controversy in the reported β value for ZnO. For example, Boemare et al. [19] reported 240 K, Chichibu et al. [20] reported 380 K and Hamby et al. [21] reported 390 K. The values of β reported in this study are in good agreement with those previously reported by Chichibu et al. [20] and Hamby et al. [21].
After the optical characterization of the a-plane ZnO, we have compared the PL emissions with those of a c-plane ZnO (0001) one.

As shown in Fig. 5, we have represented on the same graph the evolution of the energy of the A free exciton as a function of the temperature for a-plane and c-plane ZnO layers. The analysis of the curves obtained showed that the A free exciton in the a-plane ZnO layer is always located at higher energy. This confirms the energy difference between the A free exciton in a-plane layer and c-plane layer, measured at 10 K (see Table 3). The inset of Fig. 5 shows the spectra of PL and reflectivity at 10 K of the a-plane and c-plane ZnO layers. The curves (a) and (b) represent the reflectivity and PL spectra respectively and the curve (c) represents the PL spectrum of the c-plane ZnO layer.
Fig. 5
Comparison of temperature dependence of a-plane ZnO A free excitons with c-plane ZnO A free excitons. In the inset, the a-plane ZnO PL (b) and reflectivity (a) at 10 K are superposed to the c-plane ZnO spectrum (c) at 10 K. The spectra are displaced vertically
Table 3
Comparison of free exciton energy positions in c-plane and a-plane samples at 10 K

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: In summary, we have investigated the temperature- and polarization-dependent reflectivity and photoluminescence of undoped a-plane ZnO. Our results indicate that our a-plane-oriented ZnO layer is of high optical quality. We have identified the bound exciton and A, B and C free exciton transitions. The energy positions of the A free exciton as a function of temperature are presented. Our results also demonstrate that the A–B free excitons in a-plane ZnO have a blue shift always higher than 20 meV in comparison to those of conventional c-plane material. Finally, the strong emission observed in the region of the 1LO phonon related to defects, as already confirmed, disappears above 150 K and the spectrum is composed of the emissions of the free exciton and its phonon replicas.
